Graphical abstract Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts for hydrodesulfurization (HDS) were prepared from a new amorphous MoS2 precursor and tris-(N,N-dimethyldithiocarbamato)-cobalt(III) as promoter source. The samples were obtained by thermal decomposition in either forming gas atmosphere (H2/N2) or nitrogen atmosphere at three different temperatures (350, 380 and 410°C). The catalytic activities and selectivity for the HDS reaction exhibit surprising results. The set of catalysts activated in forming gas show a clear preference for the direct desulfurization (DDS) path, while samples activated in nitrogen are less active for the DDS route. This result indicates a better Co dispersion over the edges of MoS2 nanocrystallites in the catalysts synthesized in H2/N2. The activation temperature is shown to be an important factor for the catalytic activity. The most active catalysts prepared in H2/N2 and N2 were treated at 380 and 410°C, respectively. Phase segregation of Co sulfide species could be observed for all catalysts before the HDS, while after the catalytic tests most of the Co species vanished. The most active catalysts exhibit the lowest stacking of MoS2 layers and the shortest slab lengths. The catalysts are intensively characterized by means of chemical analyses, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and the reasons for the differences in selectivity and activity during the HDS reaction are revealed and discussed. Keywords Amorphous MoS2 Thermal decomposition Activation atmosphere Hydrodesulfurization Selectivity 1 Introduction The combustion of mineral oil products is one of the most important processes to produce energy on our planet. Petroleum products are presently consumed in enormous quantities due to their high energy densities and convenient physical form, and the major petroleum products are transportation fuels. But during combustion of the fuels, environmental unfriendly pollutants like SO x , CO, NO x , particulates, olefins and aromatic hydrocarbons are emitted. Various hydrotreating processes are used to improve the fuel quality, to reduce air pollution emissions, to avoid poisoning of noble metals and acid catalysts used in catalytic reforming and cracking. An important hydrotreating process deals with the removal of sulfur via catalytic hydrodesulfurization (HDS). The catalysts used for HDS are generally based on MoS2 being promoted by either Co or Ni. Although MoS2 is known for decades, its full potential in various applications is yet to be discovered. In addition to its use as a catalyst in the hydrotreatment [1–10], it is being utilized as lubricant [11–13], electrode material for Mg and Li ion batteries [14–16] as well as catalyst in photochemistry [17–19]. Various methods of preparation have been applied to synthesize MoS2-based catalysts with different properties among others the thermal decomposition of precursors [20–23], solvothermal routes [24], sulfurization of oxide species [25,26] and chemical vapor deposition [27] just to name a few. The most widely used synthesis approach to generate Mo or W sulfide catalysts for HDS starts from oxidic precursors which are then sulfurized using either H2/H2S or an organic sulfur compound like dimethyl disulfide (DMDS). The disadvantage of this preparation method is that complete sulfidation can often not be achieved especially for W-based catalysts [28–31], and in the case of catalysts supported on oxidic materials, the support often interacts with the catalyst leading to a lower degree of sulfidization. This problem can be avoided by using a precursor like ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (ATM, (NH4)2MoS4) or corresponding alkyl ammonium tetrathiomolybdates. In combination with promoter carriers like, for instance, Co or Ni carbamates, Ni or Co diethylenetriamine tetrathiomolybdates or other thiosalts and subsequent thermal decomposition in nitrogen or forming gas atmosphere, these compounds form catalysts with excellent performances without any participation of oxygen during the synthesis [20–23,32]. The activity of these catalysts depends on many different factors, like the essential synergism between the promoter Co or Ni and Mo which has mostly been attributed to electronic effects [33]. The promoter atoms decrease the strength of the MoS bond and increase the electron density on the sulfur atoms [34,35]. As a consequence, the basicity of the S species on the surface increases and by that the CS bond cleavage is facilitated. Another important role on activity, though it is not fully understood, is ascribed to carbon on the surface of or within the catalyst [36–38]. It is suggested that the carbon stabilizes the catalysts active phase by replacing excess sulfur on the surface of MoS2, which leads to MoS x C y phases with carbidic species (so-called carbosulfide phases). Recently, we reported the preparation of Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts by thermal decomposition of a mixture of cobalt diethylenetriamine tetrathiomolybdate and tetrapropylamine tetrathiomolybdate [39]. Tests of the HDS activity on dibenzothiophene (DBT) were carried out under the same conditions as the catalysts in this study. We also studied the effect of ex situ and in situ activation on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. In our ongoing work, we developed a new synthesis strategy for the preparation of Co-promoted catalysts. Here we present a completely new synthesis route applying a new precursor material as MoS2 source. In a first step, amorphous MoS2 is prepared by decomposition of ATM in a hydrazine atmosphere at room temperature followed by impregnation with Co dimethyl-dithiocarbamate. During the activation process at elevated temperature, the promoter and also carbon are incorporated into the MoS2 catalyst. The focus of this paper is a comparison of the activation of the catalysts in different gas atmospheres and the selectivity ratio HYD/DDS (Hydrogenation/Direct Desulfurization) of the HDS reaction. For establishing a relation between catalytic behavior and structural/chemical properties, the samples are characterized with X-ray powder diffractometry, chemical analyses, nitrogen sorption measurements, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The starting materials were obtained in high purity from Sigma-Aldrich. By addition of 30g of ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) to 200mL of a 25wt% solution of ammonia and bubbling H2S for half an hour through the solution the precursor ammonium tetrathiomolybdate ((NH4)2MoS4), ATM) was obtained as red crystals. The ATM sample was ball milled for 1h in inert atmosphere. Amorphous MoS2 was then synthesized by the following procedure: typically 10mL of hydrazine were placed on a Petri dish into the lower chamber of a desiccator and 2g ATM are spread on another Petri dish and stored above the Petri dish with the hydrazine. The reduction of ATM is recognized by a change in color from red to anthracite and is completed in about 20–30 days. The final product is insoluble in conventional solvents like H2O, CH3CN, alcohols, etc. The complete reduction of ATM was confirmed by treating the product with water. No red color occurred, indicating full decomposition of ATM. After completion of the reaction, the Petri dish was taken out and kept in another desiccator containing silica granules as desiccant for yet another day for thorough drying after which the product was weighed. The second precursor tris-(N,N-dimethyldithiocarbamato)-cobalt(III) (Co[S2CN(CH3)2]3, Co(DMTC)3) was obtained by solving 0.86g cobalt acetate in 100mL water and adding 100mL of water with 1g of dissolved sodium dimethyl-dithiocarbamate. The green precipitate was filtered and washed with water. The precursor was prepared by mixing Co(DMTC)3 and amorphous MoS x . One gram (6.24mmol) of MoS x and 0.75g (2.5mmol) of Co(DMTC)3 were used to achieve an atomic ratio of Co/(Co+Mo) of 0.3. After treatment in a ball mill for 1h in Argon atmosphere, the mixtures were heated at different temperatures and in different atmospheres to activate the catalysts. Six samples were prepared: three samples were heated in a flow of nitrogen (1.4Lmin−1 flow rate, in a rotating furnace (500rpm)) and another three in a flow of forming gas (same conditions, with 10% of H2 in N2). All samples were treated at different temperatures as indicated in Table 1 . The temperatures were chosen because the amorphous MoS x precursor starts to crystallize at 350°C. Hence, using different activation temperatures in different gas atmospheres allow studying the textural and structural evolution of the catalysts which are related to the catalytic performance in the HDS reaction. The samples before the HDS tests are labeled PXCo1-3 and PXCo4-6, while the samples recovered after the HDS test are labeled PXCo1-3m and PXCo4-6m. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder patterns were recorded on a STOE STADI-P instrument (monochromatized Cu Kα1 radiation, λ =1.54056Å) in transmission mode with a position sensitive detector. Chemical analyses were performed with a EURO Vector EA Combustion analyzer using zinc sample holders. The samples were heated up to 1000°C under oxygen atmosphere and the gases were detected by a thermal conductivity cell. Nitrogen adsorption measurements were carried out at 77K on a Quantachrom Autosorb-1. Samples were degassed under flowing argon at 200°C for 2h before N2 adsorption. The BET surface areas were calculated from p/p 0 =0.03–0.3 in the adsorption branch. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) investigations were performed with a Tecnai 30 STwin microscope (300kV, FEG cathode, C s =1.2mm). Small amounts of powdered catalysts were suspended in butanol and ultrasonically grinded for 3–5min. Afterwards the suspended powder was transferred on a TEM support (a lacey carbon film on 200-mesh copper grid) by placing 1–2 droplets of the suspension onto the sample grid. The prepared TEM samples were dried at room temperature for several minutes. All images were recorded with a Gatan Multiscan CCD camera (2k×2k) and evaluated (including Fourier analyses) with a Gatan software package Digital Micrograph 1.8. EDS analyses were performed in TEM mode with a Si/Li detector (EDAX System). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) micrographs were filtered by Wiener HRTEM filter which was integrated in the Gatan Digital Micrograph software. The computer simulation of the experimental HRTEM micrographs was carried out by utilizing the multislice approach incorporated in the software package JEMS [40]. Rotational average profiles were generated via a plug-in script (Difftool) of Digital Micrograph software (Gatan). For the background subtraction of the rotational average profiles, a self-written program was applied to fit an exponential decay curve in the minima of the profile and then subtract the fitted background. The HDS of DBT was tested in a high-pressure 300mL Parr reactor by placing 4.4g DBT, 100mL of decaline and 0.3g of the catalysts applied in the as-prepared state. The reactor was purged of residual air, pressurized with H2 to 3.1MPa (450psi) and then heated to the reaction temperature of 350°C in about 10min. A stirring rate of 600rpm was used. The progress of the reaction was monitored by gas chromatography with a HP 6890 gas chromatograph, using samples taken every 20min during the first hour, then every 30min for the next 4h. Reduction of the sample volume due to sampling was ≤5% of total volume. The identity of the reaction products was confirmed by mass spectrometry with a HP 6890 GC-MS, using a HP-5MS capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). The catalytic activity is expressed in terms of percentage conversion of DBT vs. reaction time, and from these data, the reaction rates were calculated for each catalyst. The mean standard deviation for catalytic measurements was about 2.5%. The HDS of DBT yields biphenyl (BP) through the direct desulfurization pathway (DDS), and tetrahydrodibenzothiophene (THDBT), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB), very low amounts of dicyclohexane (DCH) and of cyclohexylcyclopentylmethane (CHCPM) through the hydrogenation pathway (HYD). Since these two pathways are parallel and the amounts of DCH and CHCPM are very small, the selectivity ratio (HYD)/(DDS) can be calculated with the equation HYD/DDS=([THDBT]+[CHB])/[BP] without affecting the value for the selectivity. In any case, we also calculated the selectivity including DCH and CHCPM (see Fig. S1). 3 Results 3.1 General The motivation for the synthesis of an amorphous precursor by decomposition of ATM in a hydrazine atmosphere bases on the following considerations: (i) once the nucleation barrier has been overcome single layers of MoS2 start to grow producing a catalyst with low stacking degree; (ii) the chemical analysis of the precursor evidenced the presence of adsorbed hydrazine molecules [41], which should facilitate the reduction of Co(III) to Co(II) during the decomposition process; (iii) during the thermal decomposition being accompanied by the formation of the MoS2 slabs, a good dispersion of the promoter Co should be achievable. In Table 2 , the elemental analyses data of the samples PXCo1 to PXCo3 activated in forming gas before and after the HDS measurement and additionally of the amorphous MoS x precursor are listed. The ratio of Mo:S is 1:2.1 slightly exceeding the ratio for MoS2. As the precursor Co(DMTC)2 contains carbon, the catalysts show a specific carbon content after activation despite the fact that the precursor is completely decomposed as evidenced by the absence of hydrogen. After the HDS reaction, the carbon content is significantly higher because remnants of the reaction species—educts and products—remain in the sample. The hydrogen content, though not significant before the HDS measurement, rises to values of about 0.6–0.8wt% which is in good agreement with the increase of the carbon content after the HDS. The sulfur content is quite large with values of about 40wt%, which leads to ratios of Mo:S of about 1:2.5 before the HDS reaction. The fact that the XRD patterns show various Co sulfide species may explain the excess sulfur (Figs. 2 and 3 ). After the HDS reaction, this ratio drops to values of about 1:2, as expected for a MoS2 catalyst. Table 3 shows the same data for the samples PXCo4 to PXCo6 activated in nitrogen. There are distinct differences between the two series of catalysts: (i) the nitrogen content is much higher for the samples activated in N2 atmosphere; (ii) the carbon content in the range of 0.9–1.0wt% is slightly higher than in the samples obtained in forming gas (0.6–0.8wt%); (iii) the samples contain hydrogen directly after the activation. These three major differences indicate that the precursor Co(DMTC)3 may not completely decomposed during the activation process or that fragments of volatile species are trapped in the catalyst or on the surface of the samples. IR spectra of the catalysts give no indications for intact DMTC or any other organic molecule. The samples obtained in nitrogen gas exhibit a slightly lower S content yielding a Mo:S ratio of about 1:2.3. The XRD patterns of these samples show reflections of cobalt sulfide species (see below) which explains the excess of sulfur content, although the S content is lower than for the catalysts prepared in forming gas. After the HDS reaction, the sulfur content is lowered like observed for the samples obtained in forming gas but not to the stoichiometric ratio of Mo:S=1:2. The XRD patterns of these samples recorded after HDS show also weak reflections of a Co sulfide which explains the excess sulfur. Additionally, the nitrogen content decreases from PXCo4 to PXCo6, indicating that N species are removed during the hydrotreating process. The nitrogen sorption measurements reveal that all samples have a relatively low specific surface area ranging between about 6 and 12m2/g. The largest value was obtained for PXCo2 and PXCo6 (11.7 and 10.6m2/g), while for all other catalysts the value is 6±0.5m2/g. We note that these values are relatively low compared to data reported in literature [42]. 3.2 Microstructure of the MoS2 slabs of the catalysts Fig. 1 displays the XRD patterns of the amorphous molybdenum sulfide precursor after the hydrazine treatment of ATM, the same precursor after heating to 450 and 900°C and the calculated pattern for microcrystalline MoS2. The pattern of the as-prepared material shows only broad modulations typical for the absence of long-range order (being reminiscent of a glass-like state) of the structure. After heating at elevated temperature (here T =450°C as example), the precursor shows the typical XRD pattern of nanosized 2H-MoS2 which exhibits small coherent scattering domains and a low stacking number of ca. 4 (i.e. average no. MoS2 layers within each coherently scattering domain) as calculated by the Scherrer formula. The (002) reflections are shifted to a smaller scattering angle compared to the position in the calculated pattern, indicating an expansion of the interlayer space, which may be caused by molecules located within the van der Waals gaps of MoS2 layers. Moreover, the expansion of interlayer distance could be interrelated to the low stacking number of the slabs [43]. The evolution of the background at low scattering angles indicates the presence of uncorrelated single and few slabs of MoS2. The virtual absence of the (103) and (105) reflections demonstrates that individual MoS2 layers are rotated and shifted against each other (turbostratic disorder) [44,45]. Increasing the temperature to 900°C leads to sharpening of the reflections due to increased crystallinity of the material and applying the Scherrer formula the stacking number is estimated to be 17. But the (002) reflection is still broader than that of bulk MoS2 and the MoS2 structure is still turbostratically disordered. The results obtained on the precursor suggest that catalysts with a low stacking of MoS2 slabs should be formed during simultaneous thermal decomposition with Co(DMTC)3. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) investigations were carried out to analyze the microstructures of the samples, in order to find the structure–property correlation of the catalysts. In the following, the features of the two most active catalysts (PXCo2 and PXCo6) prepared in forming gas and N2 atmosphere, respectively, were compared in terms of the microstructures of particles consisting of MoS2 slabs both before and after HDS reaction. The structural features were determined using methods covering a broad range of length scales. The quantitative interpretation of SAED patterns enables to examine structural ordering within circular transmitted areas of 250nm in diameter, thus, enhancing considerably the lateral resolution of XRD experiments. HRTEM imaging close to atomic resolution allows performing structure analyses on single nanoparticles including partially ordered aggregates of MoS2 slabs. Based on this combined approach, the crystallinity of MoS2 in samples PXCo2 and PXCo6 is compared to two catalysts (PXCo3 and PXCo4) which were the least active in the HDS reaction. Representative HRTEM micrographs were selected to generate an overview of the microstructure evolution of the catalysts due to the influences of synthesis parameters and HDS reaction. With the help of HRTEM imaging, it is quite evident that in sample PXCo2 (synthesized in H2/N2 atmosphere) the length and stacking number of the MoS2 layers became larger after the HDS reaction (cf. Fig. 3a and b). The latter result is supported by Fourier analyses of corresponding micrographs (not shown). On the other hand, the particles of sample PXCo6 (highest catalytic activity), which were formed in N2 atmosphere contain more randomly arranged and bent single slabs of MoS2 as compared to PXCo2 (cf. Fig. 3c). Such microstructural feature gives rise to a more pronounced exposure of the catalytically active sites located mostly on the edges of the single slabs and in turn explains its highest HDS activity of all the as-prepared materials. After HDS, the MoS2 layers in PXCo6 evolved into slightly longer slabs with more pronounced parallel stacking of the consecutive layers (cf. Fig. 3d). The stacking number for sample PXCo6 became more pronounced after HDS than that of PXCo2, suggesting that the HDS process exerted more influence on the microstructure of MoS2 in the sample prepared in N2 than that in forming gas. 3.3 Dispersion of the Co-promoter The X-ray powder patterns of the catalysts prepared in the two different atmospheres before the HDS reaction are displayed in Figs. 3 and 4 . Obviously, the catalysts obtained in forming gas (Fig. 3) are nanocrystalline but some weak reflections of crystalline Co3S4 and Co9S8 can also be detected. The Co3S4 particle sizes were estimated by using the Scherrer formula yielding values between 13 (PXCo1) and 16nm (PXCo2/PXCo3). The intensities of the reflections of the Co9S8 are too low for a meaningful analysis with the Scherrer approach. In contrast, weak reflections of a Co-poor sulfide (Co1−x S) are seen in the patterns of the second series of catalysts (Fig. 4, N2), which have particle sizes of about 33, 24 and 18nm from PXCo4 to PXCo6. For both types of catalysts, broad modulations corresponding to the (002), (100), (103) and (110) reflections associated with 2H-MoS2 are observed, which are less well developed for the catalysts synthesized in N2 (compare Figs. 3 and 4). The fact that the reflections are very broad indicates that the materials consist of nanosized coherent scattering domains with a low stacking number and a pronounced disorder [46–48]. It seems that the materials prepared in N2 atmosphere are significantly less ordered than those obtained in forming gas. In all patterns, the scattering region below the (002) reflection is characteristic for single MoS2 layers and/or amorphous materials. For the samples obtained in forming gas (PXCo1 → PXCo3), the reflections of Co3S4 and Co9S8 become slightly more intense with increasing activation temperature (Fig. 3), while for the catalysts prepared in N2 (PXCo4 → PXCo6) the intensity of the reflections of Co1−x S decrease as the temperature increases (Fig. 4). This observation suggests that the Co species in the latter samples are less good dispersed at low temperatures and dispersion becomes better at higher temperatures, while the opposite is observed for catalysts activated in forming gas, i.e. a more pronounced phase segregation occurs at higher temperatures. But comparing the intensities of the reflections of the Co sulfides in the two different series of catalysts, it is obvious that the crystallite sizes in PXCo4-6 (N2 samples) are significantly larger than in the catalysts PXCo1-3 (H2/N2 samples) indicating a better dispersion of Co in these materials. The cobalt sulfide species can be ordered ranging from rich in sulfur (CoS2) over medium sulfur contents (Co3S4, Co1−x S) to sulfur-poor sulfides (Co9S8, Co4S3). The decomposition in forming gas atmosphere leads to the formation of the sulfur-poor cobalt species Co9S8 and Co3S4 because the hydrogen in the forming gas reduces the sulfur content due to the formation of H2S even at low temperatures. Co3S4, on the other hand, is favored over Co9S8 in the higher temperature region, which is why the amount of Co3S4 increases with increasing temperature. In the nitrogen atmosphere, the sulfur content is not significantly reduced and thus the more sulfur rich phase Co1−x S is formed. The higher the temperature, the more cobalt is dispersed and thus the cobalt sulfide phase formation is less pronounced. To confirm the distribution of the cobalt promoter among the MoS2 phase, electron diffraction and HRTEM simulation were applied. The catalytically most active sample PXCo6 is especially of interest. Before HDS, one can refer from the SAED pattern shown in Fig. 5b that the Bragg reflections on concentric diffraction rings can be assigned to the lattice planes of Co1−x S (space group: P63/mmc), proving the presence of polycrystalline cobalt sulfide particles within the transmitted area being consistent with the XRD results (cf. Fig. 4). Moreover, the reflections from the MoS2 phase were extremely weak in the SAED pattern due to the presence of single slabs in this region, as it is also shown unambiguously in the HRTEM micrographs of Fig. 3c and 5a. The HRTEM imaging does not show any lattice fringes assigned to cobalt sulfide crystals, indicating the cobalt sulfide phases were well dispersed and embedded inside the MoS2 matrix, which is in line with the findings from XRD. After HDS, the HRTEM micrograph depicts a more condensed arrangement of the MoS2 slabs, and rarely Co9S8 nanocrystals (Fig. 5c). Fig. 5d shows a Wiener filtered HRTEM micrograph of the lattice fringes of highly crystalline Co9S8, which was indexed to be along the [101] zone axis. Additionally, a computer simulation utilizing the multislice method was performed in order to further confirm the cobalt sulfide species identified by HRTEM imaging. The simulated micrograph is inserted in Fig. 5d, presenting a fairly good match with the experimental data. However, the contrast modulation of brighter and darker spots as observed in the experimental micrograph are not reproduced by simulation and could probably originate from an overlapping of the Co9S8 nanocrystal with an amorphous region of Co sulfide underneath it. Nanoprobe EDX spectroscopy evidences the presence of amorphous Co sulfide phases in several regions of the samples displaying partially a high content of Co even though no crystalline particles were observed via HRTEM imaging. Therefore, the existence of amorphous Co rationalizes the excessive sulfur content detected in the elemental analyses (cf. Tables 2 and 3). In the case of sample PXCo2, the S content of the amorphous Co-containing species is frequently reduced implying the presence of amorphous Co. Furthermore, in good agreement with the result from XRD, the Co3S4 phase was also observed via TEM in PXCo3 prepared in forming gas, which is supposed to contain the highest concentration of Co3S4. To conclude, the morphologies of Mo–S particles containing MoS2 slabs and the nature of the different cobalt promoters observed by TEM are consistent with those found by XRD. 3.4 Structural evolution of the catalysts During the HDS reaction, the samples undergo major structural changes and the XRD patterns of the samples change significantly. In the X-ray powder patterns of the samples prepared in forming gas, no reflections of cobalt sulfide species can be detected (Fig. 3). The XRD pattern of PXCo4m synthesized in N2 atmosphere (Fig. 4) shows weak reflections of Co9S8 instead of Co1−x S as observed before the HDS test, while in the patterns of PXCo5m/PXCo6m, these reflections can hardly be seen. The small features located at around 31° 2θ may be regarded as a hint for particles with sizes near the coherence length of the X-rays. The particle size of Co9S8 in PXCo4m was estimated with the Scherrer equation to about 18nm, i.e. the particles are significantly smaller than before the HDS reaction (before: 33nm). The observations that no crystalline Co sulfide particles could be detected in the XRD patterns of the forming gas samples (PXCo1m-3m) or were transformed from a Co-poor to a Co-rich sulfide (PXCo4m) can be explained by a chemical reaction under the reducing conditions (H2) at T =350°C. The crystalline Co sulfide species observed before the HDS test are nanosized and it is well documented that such nanoparticles are much more chemically reactive than bulk materials due to the presence of a large amount of atoms on the surface of the crystallites. The high chemical reactivity but also a high mobility of the atoms on the particle surface explains the observation of a structural reorganization from Co1−x S to Co9S8. No reflections of crystalline metallic Co can be detected in the XRD patterns, thus one can assume that Co atoms are distributed within the catalysts. Whether the Co atoms are re-dispersed in the sense that they are located on the edges of MoS2 slabs cannot be answered from X-ray powder diffractometry. The intensity of the reflections of the Co sulfide phase for the catalysts obtained in nitrogen atmosphere follows the trend observed before the HDS reaction, i.e. a decrease of the reflections’ intensity is observed with increasing preparation temperature. Comparing the features of the MoS2-related reflections in the powder patterns of the two series of catalysts, some remarkable differences are obvious. The samples prepared in forming gas exhibit a lower stacking of the MoS2 slabs (Fig. 3) than the catalysts treated in N2 (Fig. 4). In addition, the reaction conditions of the HDS induce no pronounced changes of the intensity and width of the (002) reflection (Fig. 3) indicating only small changes in the stacking of MoS2 slabs. The situation is different for the samples heated in N2 where the (002) reflections of PXCo4m-6m are more intense after the HDS test. All these observations are in full agreement with analyses of HRTEM images (see below). Finally, the small angle scattering region of all samples still indicates the presence of MoS2 single slabs. A detailed analysis of the stacking degree and the slab length before and after HDS (Fig. 6 ) was performed to gain further insights into the nanostructure of the catalysts. The four catalysts were selected to compare the nanostructural features of the two most active materials (PXCo2, PXCo6) with the two least good catalysts (PXCo3, PXCo4). The most prominent observations are: (i) before HDS PXCo2 and PXCo6 exhibit the lowest stacking of MoS2 slabs with most particles showing three to seven stacked layers, while for PXCo3 the maximum is located at higher stacking number (around nine slabs) and PXCo4 exhibits a broad distribution of stacking numbers with many MoS2 crystallites composed of seven to eleven slabs; (ii) after HDS, PXCo2 still has a low stacking degree, but additionally also some particles are present composed of more MoS2 slabs and PXCo6 seems to be more affected by the reaction conditions with crystallites showing a broader stacking distribution than before HDS; (iii) for PXCo3, the overall stacking is similar after HDS while for PXCo4 the broad distribution of stacked MoS2 slabs is narrowed and the maximum is around six stacks MoS2 slabs; (iv) the slab length distribution of PXCo2 is narrow before and clearly larger after HDS whereas for PCo6 no significant changes can be detected; (v) the situation is different for PXCo3 with short slabs before the HDS reaction and a much broader distribution after HDS, while PXCo4 showed longer MoS2 slabs before HDS and even longer slabs after the test. Overall, the observations made with these analyses are in full agreement with the results obtained with X-ray powder diffractometry. The results also demonstrate that the different catalysts are affected in partially very different ways. For a more statistic interpretation of the crystallinity of the MoS2 catalysts from the TEM data, a quantification of rotational average from the SAED patterns was carried out. The SAED patterns were obtained from selected areas containing only MoS2 slabs. In principle, the rotational average profiles represent the one-dimensional intensity profile of a two-dimensional SAED pattern. These profiles are obtained by integration of the intensities of each diffraction ring over an angular range from 0° to 359°, starting from the origin of the primary beam in a SAED pattern. In this manner, the vertical axis of the rotational average profile represents the diffracted intensity of a corresponding diffraction ring, and the horizontal axis represents the location of the diffraction rings in reciprocal space. As shown in Fig. 7 , the rotational average profiles were background subtracted using our own software and normalized to be compared with each other. Each peak on the profile is correlated to a specific diffraction ring (or non-resolved multiples) on the SAED pattern. Before HDS, the (002) reflection was the most intense one in the rotational average profiles, which agrees with a kinematic calculation based on randomly dispersed MoS2 crystallites (see Fig. S4a). The agreement between the simulated rotational average profile with the experimental one might be due to the reason that in the model of finite spherical crystal, the MoS2 slabs and their aggregates more resembles nanosized crystallites, and they are preferably arranged that the Bragg condition for (002) reflections is fulfilled. Such preferential orientation of the (002) planes would lead to a much higher relative intensity in comparison to random rotational average profile. After HDS, the intensity of the (100) and (103) reflections were much more pronounced or even exceeded that of the (002) reflection (cf. intensity ratios presented in Table 6, for sample PXCo2, PXCo3 and PXCo4). These observations indicate an evolution of more observable structural ordering according to the (100) and (103) planes vs (002) planes in the SAED experiment. This finding is somewhat surprising taking into account the larger stacking number of the (002) plane after HDS as observed by HRTEM. However, the observations can be rationalized considering a combined effect of increasing stacking number and layered texture of the MoS2 particles: since the stacking of the MoS2 (002) basal planes increases, the layered morphology of MoS2 particles becomes more pronounced. Consequently, the initially observed strong intensity for (002) should decrease and the normally observed texture for particles with a layered structure should become dominant, i.e. the (002) planes are preferably arranged perpendicular to the beam thus less contributing to diffracted intensity. Furthermore, the d-spacing determined from the position of the (002) peak is in general decreasing after HDS and more close to the calculated value for the bulk material (measured from the rotational average profile, not shown). This finding also indicates that the arrangement of MoS2 (002) slabs after HDS approximates the one of the bulk material and it is also validated by the dynamic simulation of the rotational average profile which is based on a structure model of infinite numbers of crystals (see Fig. S4b). The observations of an enhanced crystallinity of MoS2 in the samples PXCo2m, PXCo3m and PXCo4m (after HDS) are in good agreement with the XRD experiment. The rotational average profiles did not vary significantly for PXCo4 and PXCo6 both before and after HDS, which is also observed in XRD measurement. 3.5 Catalytic performance—activity and selectivity The most interesting result of the catalytic HDS tests is the significant difference in selectivity of the two series of catalysts and the differing activity of the samples. The results of the catalytic tests are summarized in Table 4 , and details about products formed during HDS of DBT are listed in Table 5 . While the catalysts activated in forming gas atmosphere show a clear preference for the DDS pathway (HYD/DDS around 0.3), the samples activated in nitrogen atmosphere exhibit a less pronounced preference for DDS (HYD/DDS=0.70–0.85) (see Fig. 8 ). The catalysts PXCo1–3 (forming gas) show on average higher conversion rates than the catalysts PXCo4–6 (nitrogen), and only PXCo6 (nitrogen) exhibits a larger conversion rate (42%) (Fig. 9 ). The rate constants of the catalysts obtained in forming gas show a slight decrease with increasing activation temperature, while a pronounced opposite trend is observed for the materials activated in N2, i.e. an increase of the activation temperature yields larger rate constants. Fig. 10 displays the evolution of the selectivity of the different catalysts using: HYD/DDS=([THDBT]+[CHB])/[BP] Keeping in mind the accuracy of quantitative determination of the HDS products, no significant change of the selectivity can be observed for PXCo1-3 (H2/N2) over the reaction time (Fig. 10). The slightly different behavior of PXCo1 at the beginning of the HDS reaction including DCH and CHCPM in the selectivity calculation may be explained by a short activation period (see Fig. S1). The catalysts prepared in N2 (PXCo4-6) exhibit a different behavior with a continuous change of the selectivity for hydrogenation products (Fig. 10). These catalysts behave slightly different at the beginning of the HDS reaction taking into account DCH/CHCPM (Fig. S1) which is caused by an activation/induction at the early stages (see below). Fig. 11 depicts the relative evolution of the different products during the HDS of DBT over 5h. The primary observation is that for all samples, the favored product is BP produced by the DDS pathway (see Fig. S2) and no pronounced change of the amount of BP is observed over the whole 5h. We note that the amount of BP is clearly larger for PXCo1-3 (H2/N2) than for PXCo4-6 (N2). The formation of BP is directly associated with a good dispersion of Co on the edges of the MoS2 slabs and as discussed above (Figs. 3 and 4) the catalysts PXCo1-3 exhibit a better dispersion of Co than the remaining three catalysts explaining the larger BP production of the forming gas samples. The small increase of the amount of BP at the beginning of the DBT conversion may be caused by a type of re-dispersion of Co from the nanocrystalline Co sulfides to the edges of MoS2 slabs. The two products THDBT and CHB are formed via the hydrogenation pathway. The amount of THDBT is larger for all catalysts prepared in N2 compared to the samples obtained in H2/N2, at least in the beginning of the reaction and the concentration is reduced in favor of CHB as the reaction proceeds [2]. HHDBT and CHEB are both intermediates of the formation of CHB but are not detected as their lifetime is very short. The increasing concentrations of CHB indicate an increasing HYD activity in the course of the HDS reaction, which is associated with an increase of stacking of MoS2 slabs (see Fig. 6), because a more pronounced stacking reduces the amount of edge sites in a catalyst where the sulfur atom of DBT can coordinate for DDS. The two products of hydrogenation CHCPM and DCH do not play a significant role for the forming gas samples as can be seen form the low concentrations in Fig. 11. In contrast, appreciable amounts of CHCPM could be detected especially at the beginning of the HDS reaction, while at later stages the concentration decreases. 4 Discussion The Co-promoted MoS2-based catalysts were prepared using a new synthetic approach applying amorphous hydrazine containing MoS x , which was obtained by reacting ATM in hydrazine atmosphere at room temperature. More details about the amorphous MoS x sample can be found in yet unpublished work [41]. The promotion of the catalysts was achieved by mixing the amorphous material with CoIII(DMTC)3 adjusting the Co/(Co+Mo) atomic ratio to 0.30. The activation of the catalysts was done by thermal decomposition at three different temperatures in either forming gas or nitrogen atmosphere. The motivation for the usage of the new molybdenum sulfide precursor is based on the expectation that in situ formation of MoS2 slabs out of the amorphous state in the presence of the Co promoter may lead to an excellent dispersion of Co. In addition, increasing the decomposition temperature and applying different atmospheres should yield samples exhibiting different crystallinity with specific differences of composition and textural properties. Indeed, pronounced differences are observed for the two sets of catalysts. Samples activated in N2 have a higher nitrogen content, a slightly higher carbon content, and are less sulfur rich (Mo:S≈1:2.3) than the samples activated in forming gas (Mo:S≈1:2.5; Tables 2 and 3). The larger S content of the catalysts obtained in H2/N2 (PXCo1-3) is in line with the formation of Co3S4 and Co9S8 identified in the XRD patterns (see Fig. 3), while for the catalysts prepared in N2 (PXCo4-6) reflections of the Co poor sulfide Co1−x S are seen in the X-ray powder patterns (Fig. 4). Comparison of the intensities of the reflections of the Co sulfides in the two sets of catalysts (Figs. 3 and 4) evidences that the Co dispersion is much better in the samples obtained in H2/N2 (PXCo1-3) than in the catalysts prepared in N2 (PXCo4-6). The decomposition temperature affects the segregation of Co sulfides in the H2/N2 samples. Increasing the reaction temperature afforded a more pronounced phase separation than for the N2 catalysts for which the amount of crystalline Co sulfide decreases with raising temperature. Hence one may conclude that in none reducing atmosphere a higher temperature is required for a better Co dispersion. For both sets of catalysts, the CoIII ions of the Co precursors are partially reduced to CoII, which surprisingly seems to be more effective in N2 atmosphere. The detailed analysis of the nanostructure of the catalysts using a large number of HRTEM images demonstrates that the two best performing catalysts PXCo2 and PXCo6 (Table 4) exhibit the lowest stacking degree of MoS2 slabs and also short slabs. The catalysts PXCo3 and PXCo4 exhibiting much lower catalytic activity (Table 4) show a more pronounced stacking, a wider distribution of the number of stacked MoS2 layers and longer slabs are observed. Under the HDS reaction conditions the stacking of MoS2 layers in PXCo2/PXCo6 increased with PXCo6 being more affected (Fig. 6). Regarding the slab length, an overall elongation of MoS2 slabs is observed for PXCo2 and no significant changes are found for PXCo6. The situation is clearly different for PXCo3 and PXCo4. The number of stacked MoS2 layers is similar for PXCo3 before and after HDS, while PXCo4 exhibits a pronounced decrease of stacked slabs after HDS. In addition, the average slab length in PXCo3 is significantly larger after HDS, whereas PXCo4 displays less pronounced changes (Fig. 6). The harsh HDS reaction conditions not only change the textural properties of MoS2 nanocrystallites as evidenced by XRD and HRTEM, but also affect the nanocrystalline Co sulfides observed in the as-prepared state, which disappeared in PXCo1-3 (Fig. 3; patterns PXCo1m-3m) and also in PXCo5-6 (Fig. 4, patterns of PXCo5m-6m). Because the crystalline Co sulfide species mostly vanished after the HDS test, one may conclude that the contact synergy (remote control) model introduced by Delmon et al. can be ruled out as relevant role of Co promoting MoS2 [53]. Hence, it is more likely that Co is promoting MoS2 as proposed by the CoMoS model. The results of all analyses can be related to the catalytic performance of the samples. A better Co dispersion on the edges of MoS2 slabs explains the HYD/DDS ratio near 0.3 (Table 4) for the catalysts obtained in H2/N2 (PXCo1-3), while the less pronounced preference for the DDS pathway (Table 4 and Fig. 6) of the catalysts synthesized in N2 (PXCo4-6) indicates a less good dispersion of Co on the edges of MoS2 slabs. The slight increase in BP formation observed for PXCo4-6 (N2) (Fig. 10) at the beginning of HDS may be caused by Co dispersion over MoS2 edges. But the amount of BP never reached the value observed for the catalysts prepared in H2/N2 (PXCo1-3) and the absence of reflections of crystalline Co sulfide species in the XRD patterns of PXCo5m-6m (Fig. 4) cannot be caused by significantly increased dispersion of Co over MoS2 edges but rather by formation of finely distributed Co sulfides with sizes being too small to be detected by XRD. Indeed, EDX spectroscopy investigations revealed that regions with Co contents are present in PXCo5m-6m without any visible Co-containing crystallites. The sample PXCo4 displaying the lowest catalytic activity is characterized by a pronounced stacking of MoS2 layers and relatively long slabs (Fig. 6). This catalyst shows the lowest amount of BP production, a nearly constant amount of THDBT over the reaction time and a continuously increasing CHB formation. For all other catalysts, the THDBT concentration decreases and a crossing of the THDBT and the CHB curves is observed, which seems to occur for PXCo4 at the end of the catalytic test (Fig. 10). Finally, the formation of CHCPM is much higher for PXCo4 in the beginning of the reaction and decreases significantly until the end of the HDS test. Generally, the crossing points of the THDBT and CHB curves correlate with the activity of the samples in the forming gas and nitrogen series, respectively. The earlier the crossing during the reaction, the higher is the activity of the sample. Two further remarkable differences for the two sets of catalysts can be seen in Tables 2 and 3. The samples prepared in N2 contain appreciable amounts of nitrogen, which are reduced after the HDS reaction, but the content is still larger than in the catalysts obtained in H2/N2. In addition, the carbon content before the HDS reaction is similar for both sets of catalysts but on average higher for the samples synthesized in H2/N2. These C-containing residues may block catalytically active sites. The catalytic performance and the results of the analysis of textural and nanostructural properties indicate that the synthesis temperature and decomposition atmosphere play a crucial role. The catalyst PXCo2 (T =380°C) in the series of samples obtained in H2/N2 shows the best catalytic performance while the catalysts obtained at lower and higher temperatures are less good. This may be rationalized by the fact that low temperatures do not lead to an optimal Co dispersion and the higher temperature yields a more pronounced segregation of Co sulfide species as both the XRD and TEM data indicate. In addition, the lowest stacking degree and the shortest MoS2 layers are observed for PXCo2 in the series PXCo1-3. For catalysts PXCo4-6 (N2), the highest decomposition temperature yields the best catalyst with the lowest amount of crystalline Co sulfide, the lowest stacking of MoS2 slabs and the shortest MoS2 layers. All these results demonstrate the importance to figure out the optimal preparation conditions. The chemical analysis demonstrate that for both sets of catalysts, a reduction of the S content occurred after the HDS test yielding samples with Mo:S≈1:2 for PXCo1m-3m and ≈1:2.1 for the remaining catalysts. The higher S content of PXCo4m-6m is in line with the presence of some amorphous cobalt sulfides which could be identified by TEM/EDX analyses. By quantification of the rotational average from the SAED patterns a general observation can be made. The (002) reflection loses intensity after the HDS reaction, which is difficult to interpret due to the expected dynamical excitement of intensity. More interestingly, the intensity of the (100) and (103) reflections are much more pronounced or even exceeded that of the (002) peak after the HDS, which indicates growth of the catalyst particles in these crystallographic directions during the HDS tests. While a huge number of reports are available for supported CoMoS catalysts, where the synthesis conditions, activation atmospheres, catalyst–support interactions, etc. were studied, the data basis for unsupported CoMoS catalysts is scarce. In an earlier investigation on unsupported CoMoS catalysts prepared with [Co(dien)2]MoS4 and activated with different modes (in situ → CoMoSA and ex situ → CoMoSB) [39], we observed much larger conversion rates of 59% (CoMoSA) and 85% (CoMoSB) and the rate constants were larger as well with 2.8 and 4.1×10−6 mols−1 g−1. Both catalysts exhibited a significant preference for the DDS pathway with a selectivity of 0.15 for CoMoSA and 0.02 for CoMoSB. But these catalysts contained large amounts of carbon, and the stacking as well as slab lengths were also different for CoMoSA/CoMoSB than for the samples discussed in the present paper. It seems that carbon plays an important role for the dispersion and microstructure of the catalysts and therefore for the performance in the HDS of DBT as well as the selectivity. Alvarez et al. reported rate constants and conversion rates for unpromoted MoS2 prepared by decomposition of ATM, carbon-containing catalysts and Co promoted catalysts. MoS2, for instance, exhibits a rate constant of 0.17×10−6 mols−1 g−1 catalyst and a conversion rate of 10% DBT when activated ex situ. The best unsupported CoMoS catalyst prepared from tetramethylammonium tetrathiomolybdate and Co(NO3)2·6H2O showed a rate constant of about 1.5×10−6 mols−1 g−1 catalyst and 54% DBT conversion after 5h [49]. The present catalysts exhibit relatively low rate constants and low conversion rates except PXCo6 with 42% conversion and 1.79×10−6 mols−1 g−1 catalyst for the rate constant. We note that this catalyst exhibits also a very large value for HYD/DDS of 0.90, i.e. a less pronounced preference for the DDS pathway. Nava et al. studied CoMoS catalysts which were in situ activated from precursors with different carbon contents [50]. These catalysts showed merely no changes in carbon content with variation of the carbon containing precursor, but the selectivity varied in a range from 0.35 for the CoMo-H (lowest carbon content) to 0.57 for CoMo-C4 (medium carbon content) while in the study of Alvarez et al. unpromoted MoS2 showed a value for the selectivity of 1.5 [49]. This drastic change of selectivity from 1.5 for pure MoS2 to values between 0.35 and 0.57 for the promoted samples was attributed to the promoter effect of Co. The promoter effect also explained the increase in activity and the conversion rate of DBT after 5h reaction time of 9.0mols−1 g−1 and 20%, respectively. A comparison of the catalytic activity of the present catalysts with literature data evidences the synergistic effect of Co and also the good performance (see Table 4). Table 6 . 5 Conclusions The unsupported Co-promoted MoS2-based catalysts for HDS were thoroughly characterized with XRD and HRTEM measurements. The catalytic properties, specifically the selectivity, which presented itself as dependent on the activation atmosphere, could be linked to sample properties like the dispersion of Co, the slab lengths, stacking heights and defects. Various Co sulfide species were found in both series of the as-prepared catalysts, more specifically Co3S4 and Co9S8 in the H2/N2 samples and Co1−x S in the N2 samples. The cobalt sulfide species in the forming gas samples have vanished after the HDS tests, which gives rise to the assumption that the Co dispersion might have improved during the HDS test. The dispersion of the Co sulfide species of the catalysts obtained in N2 is also improved after the HDS reaction, because only the sample synthesized at the lowest temperature exhibits remaining reflections of Co sulfide species in the X-ray powder pattern. Before HDS Co1−x S was detected in the N2 samples and the observation of a more cobalt rich sulfide Co9S8 after HDS indicates a less effective dispersion for this set of catalysts. The less pronounced selectivity for the DDS pathway may be due to less good dispersion of Co compared to the catalysts obtained in H2/N2, i.e. the latter samples exhibit very low selectivity values due to the much better dispersion of Co. The activity gradient from the most active sample (PXCo6, nitrogen atmosphere) over the next active sample (PXCo2, forming gas atmosphere) to the least active sample (PXCo4, nitrogen atmosphere) can be explained by nanostructural properties like stacking of MoS2 slabs, slab lengths and defects. The two best performing catalysts (PXCo6 and PXCo2) are characterized by the shortest MoS2 slabs and the lowest stacking of the layers. coredata.dc:description: Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts for hydrodesulfurization (HDS) were prepared from a new amorphous MoS2 precursor and tris-(N,N-dimethyldithiocarbamato)-cobalt(III) as promoter source. The samples were obtained by thermal decomposition in either forming gas atmosphere (H2/N2) or nitrogen atmosphere at three different temperatures (350, 380 and 410°C). The catalytic activities and selectivity for the HDS reaction exhibit surprising results. The set of catalysts activated in forming gas show a clear preference for the direct desulfurization (DDS) path, while samples activated in nitrogen are less active for the DDS route. This result indicates a better Co dispersion over the edges of MoS2 nanocrystallites in the catalysts synthesized in H2/N2. The activation temperature is shown to be an important factor for the catalytic activity. The most active catalysts prepared in H2/N2 and N2 were treated at 380 and 410°C, respectively. Phase segregation of Co sulfide species could be observed for all catalysts before the HDS, while after the catalytic tests most of the Co species vanished. The most active catalysts exhibit the lowest stacking of MoS2 layers and the shortest slab lengths. The catalysts are intensively characterized by means of chemical analyses, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and the reasons for the differences in selectivity and activity during the HDS reaction are revealed and discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Co-promoted MoS2 for hydrodesulfurization: New preparation method of MoS2 at room temperature and observation of massive differences of the selectivity depending on the activation atmosphere
